topics.body:
Morning.

To start off the morning I read a interesting editorial, I'll summarize for clarity sake; basically the editorial in question was by a no name person, but the point he made about internet culture and geek culture was interesting.  Basically what he proposed was that internet culture and geek culture are outright taking control of mainstream culture.  What he did was that he looked up online and compared real world celebrities vs online celebrities followers; short version is that online celebrities have far more followers on average on youtube, facebook and such.

While you can say "oh that's cause they're internet celebrities" the thing to keep in mind is that "video killed the radio star" in that when television came out rather than overnight causing radio to no longer be king it was a gradual over time change.  The reason why this is relevant is that over the past four years there has been a significant reduction of people who buy cable and are just switching to netflix or such.

The reason why this is relevant is that the reduction in number of cable users is that of rising cost of paid television vs internet; at this rate the rate at which people are cutting the cord will start to drastically increase over time as the internet becomes cheaper and cheaper and faster and faster.


To summarize it: basically cable television is losing popularity because of costs whereas the internet is gaining popularity due to ever faster internet speeds thus this is compounding how popular internet stars are because traditional stars for the most part aren't tech savvy.
topics.author: 38b55cdf63616403d7560600

topics.body:
Here's some cool science shit:
UPMC is going to soon place several patients on the verge of death into suspended animation to allow doctors to have more time to operate on them.  We're obviously not talking about raising people from the dead, yet, but we are talking about science fiction cryosleep.
Estimated time: sometime this year.

Israel is planning human trials into nanobots to fight cancer this year.
Estimated time: sometime this year.

3D printed organs are becoming a reality; sure they're starting on bladders or such, but they plan on moving onto other organs later on.  In five to ten years you won't need a heart transplant, you will just get a new 3D heart printed for you.
Estimated time: sometime in the next year or two.

Scientists are working on a type of stem cell that can grow new brain cells.
Estimated time: unsure.

DARPA is planning on brain enhancements to restore memories.
Estimated time: five years.
topics.author: 38b55cdf63616403d7560600

topics.body:
"@uc9":/dis/the-time-wasting-thread/post/54d655b7636872698f6c1700#post_54d655b7636872698f6c1700
I remember the days in my childhood when people would say that cable TV would _never_ go out of style. Now here we are, with the cable companies ailing against the internet competition. Seriously. Why would anyone this day and age pay higher for movies on cables where they have next to no control of when or how they watch the movies, when we have internet services such as Netflix?
topics.author: 4fde5cee945b700a970060fc

topics.body:
"@uc9":/dis/the-time-wasting-thread/post/54d66104636872571f513300#post_54d66104636872571f513300
I hope there won't be severe *unintended* effects from these recent developments in science. I'm a little bit jittery when it comes to accepting new science stuff.

topics.body:
"@SeraphimDawn":/dis/the-time-wasting-thread/post/54d6627c63687242a0a03500#post_54d6627c63687242a0a03500
The *ONLY* way at this point to preserve things culturally at this point would be to take every last scientist, doctor, programmer or such out back and shoot them all in the head.

For example in the usa the average 18-24 year old on average has 1-3 friends.  Do I like how people's circle of friends are considerably smaller?  No, not at all, but the only way to stop this would be to shoot everyone that has a phone or computer in the head to preserve your morality.  At the rate we're technologically advancing in twenty years culturally a lot of developed countries in the world will bear no resemblance culturally to how they look today.

I guess my point is that the only way to preserve your morals is to shoot everyone that doesn't believe the same things as you. . oh hi discussion about ISIS when did you get here?
